awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Drop-in Sustainable Cathode Replacement that can Allow Sub-$100/kWh Li-ion Battery Packs with Improved Safety and Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project addresses the high cost and poor safety of Lithium-ion batteries in new energy applications. Low-cost and safe batteries will improve economic viability for solar energy storage, which is critical to increasing renewables penetration to above 30% of total power generation. This project advances a battery material to provide lower cost, higher safety and improved cyclability compared to currently used materials. This can support new batteries in applications including electric vehicles, grid-tied and solar storage, and consumer power tools, among others.

This SBIR project proposes a novel nanostructured LiMn2O4 cathode chemistry (ND-LMO) that offers ~30% lower $/kWh cost compared to incumbent nickel managanese cobalt oxides (NMC) materials. Furthermore, it will have iimproved performance parameters, such as cycle life, a safer heat generation profile, and a 10% greater amp-hour capacity between full state of charge and maximum depth of discharge. Many of these improvements stem from the “intercalation-pseudocapacitive” properties of finely nanostructured electrode materials. Technical challenges, such as inactive and deactivating surfaces, synthetic costs, and others, must be addressed for these systems to be commercially viable.  The project’s proposed composition and methods used can be applied to other material systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Task 1: Complete.

  • Successfully reproduced 100g (making 10g/batch) of optimized NanoDian LiMn2O4 (ND-LMO) cathode material which has the desired phsyical characteristics outlined in the proposal (crystal size, functional groups and porosity) which allows for cathode normalized energy density of 120mAh/g (+/-10%). Miniumum capacity reproduced in 100g:110mAh/g (Max was 133mAh/g!).

  • Successfully demonstrated coin cells with ND-LMO vs Li with good cycle life (>500 cycles at 80% capacity retention). Capacity retention of ~85% average among a tripplicate of coin cells with >110mAh/g.

Task 2: Nearing completion.

  • Reproducibly produce ≥1kg ND-LMO optimized as in Task 1. So far we have made ~300g total, we expect to reach 1kg in June (making 50g/batch).
  • Demonstrate working single-layered pouch cells using ND-LMO vs graphite with improved cycle life compared to a commercial LMO vs graphite control. We have pouch cells made and cycling, should reach 50 cycles by June.

Task 3: In planning stage.

  • Demonstrate working multi-layered pouch cells using ND-LMO vs graphite with improved cycle life compared to a commercial LMO vs graphite control. Will begin building once results from initial single-layer pouch cells are in.

  • Demonstrate improved cyclability of ND-LMO vs graphite (single or multi-layer) pouch cells at elevated temperature (~40-60°C range) compared to commercial LMO vs graphite control. Will begin testing at elevated temperatures once results from initial single-layer pouch cell at room temperature are in.

Last Modified: 02/17/2024
Modified by: Benjamin K Lesel
